author: Jim Newton
title: Former Bear Dez Clark, wife reject plea deal in disorderly conduct case Lake County News-Sun
text:
A December trial date was scheduled for former Chicago Bears tight end Desmond Clark and his wife, Maria, after the couple rejected a plea deal to resolve misdemeanor charges related to an August incident at Vernon Hills High School.
Lake County Circuit Court Judge Brian Hughes on Monday scheduled a Dec. 9 trial for the Clarks, with Desmond Clark facing a disorderly conduct charge and Maria Clark facing charges of disorderly conduct and assault. They were arrested after a dispute with Vernon Hills High School officials on Aug. 29 at the school.
Maria Clark also has a Dec. 2 trial date on misdemeanor battery charges stemming from a separate incident.

Saying he and his wife sat down this week with officials at Vernon Hills High School to discuss his family's allegations of racial slurs against their son at the school, former Chicago Bear Desmond Clark said Wednesday that he came away with assurances that all parties will work on promoting diversity.
... (Dan Moran) Assistant State's Attorney Tara Ori said Monday that she offered the Clarks a plea deal that would have resolved the charges for both cases, but it was rejected by the defendants and their attorney.
The Clarks declined to comment after their appearance in court, and their attorney, Charles Smith, said he had no comment other than that no plea agreement had been reached.
The former Chicago Bears player and his wife have been free on $25,000 bond since the incident at the high school, which their son attends.
In an earlier interview with the News-Sun, Clark said he believes the confrontation at the school was spurred by racism. He asserted that racial tension between his family and school administrators built up to an Aug. 29 outburst at the school.
Clark said the incident occurred on the heels of a school event his son had attended involving lip-syncing teams. He said his son was not allowed to participate because of a disciplinary problem, but was allowed in the audience. Clark said the teams, which were to interact with the audience, were told not to involve his son in the performance or the event.

(Laura Pavin) When his son objected, Clark said, an administrative official called him "some not so nice names." Clark said the dialogue did not include racial slurs, but there were "racial undertones" to what was said.
The Clarks turned themselves in to police after learning they had been charged after the argument with an administrator.
In a Facebook post after the incident, Clark said his son was singled out on Aug. 29 and was "implicitly called a bad student and a criminal."
Maria Clark was charged earlier in the year with battery with intent to cause bodily harm and battery involving physical contact in a separate incident that allegedly occurred May 31. According to Ori, that incident involved a conflict between Maria Clark and another person at the Target Store in Vernon Hills.
